direction.raw_text: Henry . . . Don't waste your breath. He's gone. 106   INT. BOOKSTORE - DAY                                              106 Hannah's book release party. Great turnout. Her professional PHOTO adorns a POSTER announcing the publication of Sleeping on the Moon. Boy, Hannah looks terrific in that photo. Richard hovers around the makeshift bar, drink in hand. Maureen, looking radiant, accepts the congratulations of well-wishers. TABLE prominently centered has piles of Hannah's novel, waiting to be signed. Hannah talks to the camera, looking especially radiant. This is her day and she is more than ready for her close-up. Totally different in wardrobe and appearance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Exciting, isn't it? I'm so nervous. I don't know half these people. Most of them are Richard's friends. Hannah waves to Richard. He waves back. Hannah glances around the room, as if looking for someone in particular.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nobody's showed up from my old writing group. Not one. Probably shouldn't be surprised. Haven't really heard from anyone in months. She is asked a question.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Favorite writer? You keep asking me that. Too funny. Sorry. Still can't think of one. 107   INT. BOOKSTORE - DAY                                              107 Hannah sits behind the table, signing books. Maureen stands behind her helping to orchestrate the line of people. Hannah acts very gracious. Signing a book, smiling and chatting up the guests. She seems at ease. Everything is going her way. She looks past the line. Her eyes light up and she jumps to her feet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh my God! Hannah bolts from the table, cuts through the line and finds Henry standing alone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi, Hannah.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henry. Ohhhhh. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you so much for coming. Hannah throws her arms around Henry, giving him a long heartfelt hug, almost smothering the poor guy--not that he complains. She lets go and gives Henry a friendly once-over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're the only one from the group who showed up. Still awkward for them to be around each other.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't believe you remembered my signing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, pretty hard to miss that article about you in People magazine. Just wanted to say hi. And congratulations. Maureen comes up behind Hannah. Beams at Henry, and waves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello, Henry. (To Hannah) Hannah, come back. Your public awaits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go on. They need you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please stay.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can't.   Sorry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah. Hot date. You know. Can't keep her waiting. A flight attendant.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (Buying the obvious lie) A flight attendant? Henry nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, then.     Guess you can't stay.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sorry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: One sec.   Wait here. Hannah runs back to the signing table, pulls out a book and scribbles something inside. She brings the book back over to Henry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is for you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (Protesting) Hannah . . .
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Take it. Henry accepts the book. Hannah gives him another long hug.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you want to say hello to Richard?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. No, thanks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: C'mon. It will take just a minute.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't.   Really.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dear, sweet Hannah. Please!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just say hi. Henry tries to back away. Hannah leans forward, grabs his hand and tugs him in the other direction.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've really got to -- 90.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, c'mon.   You'll -- Then -- BAM, Henry, not looking where he's going, slams into Richard accidentally, spilling Richard's drink all over the author. Horrified looks all around. 108   EXT. OUTSIDE BOOKSTORE - DAY                                       108 Outside the bookstore, Henry stands on the sidewalk, talking to the camera as he clutches Hannah's book.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I did it. I showed up to Hannah's signing. I congratulated her. I supported her, writer to writer. And I finally got introduced to Richard Benedict--formally. Sort of. Henry opens up his copy of Hannah's novel. He turns quiet, obviously moved. He holds the book up for the camera to see.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look. Hannah dedicated her novel to me. Just like she promised. Right beneath the printed dedication For Henry Obert, Hannah has written, For Henry, My Forever Friend xoxoxo Hannah. Henry studies the book for a second. Snaps it shut. 109   INT. KELLER OFFICE - DAY                                           109 Literary agent David Keller being interviewed for the camera in his office. Stacks of MANUSCRIPTS on his desk. David pulls one out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is why I love LA. True story. This guy delivers a pizza to my house one night. Then the very next week, my wife has someone come in and clean the carpets. Guess what? Same guy. Small world, isn't it? So we get talking. He tells me his name's Henry. He's a writer. He's just finished a manuscript. Offers us a discount on the carpets if I'll read ten pages. I like that thinking. So I read ten pages. Wow. I want to read ten more. Before I know it, I've read the entire book. (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just loved it. Fresh voice. Interesting characters. And that ending. David thumbs through the manuscript.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The washed-up, impotent novelist getting gunned down by Scott, the jealous, underemployed, pizza delivery man. This kid nailed it. It's on the page, know what I mean? So I intend to sign Mr. Henry Obert and get Pizza to Go out there. I predict a best seller. Probably a movie, too. I'll call him with the good news. Or maybe I'll just order a pizza. 110   INT. HENRY'S APARTMENT - DAY                                       110 Henry taking down the rejection letters from his walls and packing them in a cardboard BOX.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: David Keller did call me. One week later, he sold Pizza to Go to a New York publisher. They decided to rename it A Slice of LA. I did it. I sold my novel. Henry puts the last of the rejection letters away. Finally, he picks up a FRAMED PHOTO. INSERT shows the six members of the writing group from happier times--the photo snapped in the restaurant. Full of hope and promise.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I miss the Tuesday night group. They made me a better writer. They taught me how to handle rejection. Henry lingers on the photo before packing it away, as well. 111   INT. RESTAURANT #2 - DAY                                           111 Mostly empty. Henry sits at a booth, alone, a new copy of Gatsby in his hands. He talks to the camera. CUP OF COFFEE in front of him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hannah was right. The writing must always come first. Everything else waits. Everything. That's what I did finally. Finished my novel. (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sold it. Now? Now I'm open. Ready for whatever-- WAITRESS stops by the table, refilling Henry's cup. Then setting the pot on the table, she reaches over and snatches the copy of Gatsby. Surprised, Henry glances up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: --happens next... It's her again. That young waitress with purple streaks in her hair and matching purple glasses thumbs through the book. Henry finally checks out her name tag: Eudora. Clutching the book, Eudora recites from memory:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gatsby believed in the green light, the orgiastic future that year by year recedes before us. It eluded us then, but that's no matter--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (Surprised) --Tomorrow we will run faster, stretch out our arms further... Eudora nods. Henry is amazed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know Fitzgerald?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not intimately. He died here, you know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: December 21, 1940.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I go by there sometimes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The place on Hayworth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is that weird. That I do that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. No. Not at all. Eudora smiles, glad for the positive reinforcement.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Good. Because, you know, I don't want people to think I'm weird.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course not. Do you write?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kinda, sort of. But I'm thinking of joining a writing group. Henry bites his tongue.   Eudora nods towards the camera.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So what's this? Some kind of reality show, or something? Henry smiles. The two continue their idle chatter. CARD: EPILOGUE 112   EXT. MOBILE HOME PARK, PHOENIX -- DAY                             112 Caption reads: PHOENIX, ARIZONA.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: After a very successful book tour, John K. Butzin heard the Grand Canyon State calling. This is home now. 113   EXT. MOBILE HOME PARK (ARIZONA) -- DAY                            113 John's trailer. COSTUMED CHILDREN knock on the door while holding their trick or treat bags.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Real God-fearing Americans live here. Good people. Not those La La pussies. John opens the front door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Trick or Treat! John responds by dropping a BOOK in the first bag.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look at this treat you get. A copy of Roaring Lion by John K. Butzin. Happy Halloween. The children are dumbfounded. John moves on to the next child.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 114   INT. RESTAURANT #2 - DAY                                          114 William is back at the counter, looking as scruffy as ever. Off to the side stands a GEEKY KID, gripping a FLIP PHONE aimed directly at William. William talks to our camera.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: C'mon. Admit it. You missed me. It wasn't as interesting once I left, right? He winks.   The Kid doesn't move.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I knew the group wouldn't last without me. No way. Losers. He nods towards his companion.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Him? Oh. It's my new project. A reality TV show based on my life. You know...women I meet...thoughts that pop into my head. Kid follows me all around. 24/7. Actually I got the idea from you guys. Same concept-- just better characters. A question is asked.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Which network? Um, well...it's a...it's P-P-A...Pasadena Public Access. Oh, people watch. Yeah. We're on right after that pet psychic. A waitress's HAND reaches in and refills William's coffee cup. He likes what he sees.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thanks, babe. He looks over to Geeky Kid.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get a close-up on her. Nice and tight. William will never change.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And, hey, Kid. Lend me five bucks. I want to leave an extra special tip.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 115   INT. SCHOOL HALLWAY (LOS ANGELES) -- DAY                           115 TWO POSTERS ON EASEL in the hallway. First poster announcing:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: After I sent Colette packing, I was ready for a new chapter in my life... SATURDAY'S ADULT EDUCATION CLASSES. PUPPET MAKING meets in Room 22, and QUILTING is in Room 24. WRITING 20/20 is in Room 26. And DOG OBEDIENCE is out in the courtyard, but we already know that--the loud sound of BARKING DOGS and PEOPLE YELLING "SIT" is heard in the background. Second poster is a new version of QUIET, PLEASE--WRITERS AT WORK.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I found it teaching Adult Ed. "Writing
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: is the class. Helping writers to see. Inspired by my new self- published e-book of the same title. 116   INT. SCHOOL CLASSROOM - DAY                                        116 STUDENTS scattered around the classroom. All adult. Ethnic and demographic mix. Listening attentively. Taking notes. The DOGS continue barking outside. Alan stands in front of the class. Beaming. Excited, He CLAPS his hands once.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . You've got ten seconds. Write down the name of your character. First name that pops into mind. C'mon. Tell me your character. Students think for a second. Start scribbling a name.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Pass your names up front here. Let's see what you came up with. Students hand their papers forward. Alan starts collecting them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The right name is so important for your character. OK. What do we have?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . He looks at the first piece of paper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here's one I haven't heard. Heywood Ja-Jabloom??? That's not it.   Alan tries again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Or is it Jablom? Maybe Jablowme. Heywood Jablowme? Laughter and guffaws from the students.    Alan looks puzzled.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's so funny? Heywood Jablowme? Am I missing something? Heywood Jablowme? The students continue to laugh. Poor Alan. 117   EXT. ALAN AND COLETTE'S HOUSE - DAY                               117 Catch the FOR SALE sign posted on the front lawn. 118   EXT. COLETTE'S GARDEN - DAY                                       118 Colette engages in intense meditation on her bench. The garden around her is now dead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dr. Xiroman and I wrote our book. It actually did fairly well. INSERT BOOK. Title in large letters: Getting from Xiro to One by Dr. Xiroman in equally large letters. At the bottom of the book, in very tiny letters, reads With Colette Mooney.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dr. Phil turned us down. But we had a lovely time on Anderson. INSERT PHOTO of smiling Anderson Cooper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anderson actually wanted us back, but Dr. Xiroman and Lois Piper started dating. They eloped to Vegas last month. Off on a world cruise. INSERT PHOTO of Dr. Xiroman and Lois being married in Vegas by ELVIS.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So in less than a year, I've lost my husband, my co-author, and my agent. But I still have Nyet, Not Yet. And I will find an agent to sell my novel. Look. I bought an ad in the trades. Colette reaches for her reading glasses and shares the ad copy with us, reading aloud:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "The magic fingers that just typed the publishing world's next best selling novel are now waiting to provide free massage to interested literary agents. Experienced. Sensitive. Discreet. Memorable. No Junior Agents, please." Looking quite pleased with herself, Colette lets the copy fall away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's how I met my last husband. I think it can work again. No worries. After all, I am a graduate of -- Her iPhone starts playing music, signaling a phone call. Colette smiles in knowing satisfaction--publication is just a touch away 119   EXT. MOVIE SET -- DAY                                             119 The MOVIE CREW, on location, scurries about, trying to line up their next shot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Welcome to Sleeping on the Moon: The Movie! It's so exciting! 120   EXT. MOVIE SET -- DAY                                             120 Hannah, looking good, sits in a chair, a BOOK on her lap. She is talking to the camera. CREW in the background.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let's see. My book ended up on the best sellers list. Stopping at Number
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . She crinkles her nose in obvious disappointment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then Richard left me. (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sure the two were connected. No loss. Such an ego. But guess what? I've gone back to school! To underscore the point, she holds up a the book--it's The Great Gatsby.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look what I'm reading for class. Isn't that pretty, you know, what do they call it? What's that word? She hears an answer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ironic. That's it. Pretty ironic. But I'm going to get my degree. Then I'll be smart. Really smart. Short beat
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know how you kept asking me that question. Who's my favorite writer? Short beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Turns out I do have one. Mr. Henry Obert. He's become a great writer. A published author. She smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I knew him when. She likes her answer.    But then hesitates.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Probably shouldn't tell him I said that, 'kay? She winks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Keep it between us. Goodbye Hannah.    Good luck.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 121   EXT. FITZGERALD/GRAHAM HOME -- HOLLYWOOD - DAY                     121 HENRY (V.O.) Well, my novel finally came out. Seems to be doing OK. 122   EXT. FITZGERALD/GRAHAM HOME/SIDEWALK -- DAY                        122 Henry looks more confident. More poised. Better clothes. The frog has become the prince. He glances back at the building.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know Fitzgerald said that all good writing is swimming under water and holding your breath. He was right. But after all I've been through, I think I'm finally ready to exhale. He looks at his watch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oops. I'm late. Gotta go. 123   EXT. BOOKSTORE -- DAY                                              123 SHOPPERS coming in and out of the store. POSTER in front window announces book signing for Henry Obert, author of Slice of LA. Right next to BANNER announcing GOING OUT OF BUSINESS. And next to the banner--a YOUNG MAN leans up against the wall, waiting, passing time reading his KINDLE. 124   INT. BOOKSTORE - DAY                                               124 We jump to the woman clutching FOUR COPIES of Henry's novel. Wait a minute--we recognize those trendy glasses. It's Eudora, a rather pregnant Eudora.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, I'm totally busted. I'm buying four copies of A Slice of LA. One for each member of my writing group. Also because I think Henry Wayne Obert is the greatest new writer of the decade! Sexiest, too! Eudora is having way too much fun.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: OK. So he's my husband. I'm biased. But I still think the kid can write.
direction.name: direction
